verses.text: When they had preached the gospel to that city and had made many disciples, they returned to Lystra and to Iconium and to Antioch,

verses.name: Acts 14:22
verses.text: strengthening the souls of the disciples, encouraging them to continue in the faith, and saying that through many tribulations we must enter the kingdom of God.

verses.name: Acts 14:23
verses.text: And when they had appointed elders for them in every church, with prayer and fasting they committed them to the Lord in whom they had believed.

verses.name: Acts 14:24
verses.text: Then they passed through Pisidia and came to Pamphylia.

verses.name: Acts 14:25
verses.text: And when they had spoken the word in Perga, they went down to Attalia,

verses.name: Acts 14:26
verses.text: and from there they sailed to Antioch, where they had been commended to the grace of God for the work that they had fulfilled.

verses.name: Acts 14:27
verses.text: And when they arrived and gathered the church together, they declared all that God had done with them, and how he had opened a door of faith to the Gentiles.

verses.name: Acts 14:28
verses.text: And they remained no little time with the disciples.

verses.name: Acts 15:1
verses.text: But some men came down from Judea and were teaching the brothers, "Unless you are circumcised according to the custom of Moses, you cannot be saved."

verses.name: Acts 15:2
verses.text: And after Paul and Barnabas had no small dissension and debate with them, Paul and Barnabas and some of the others were appointed to go up to Jerusalem to the apostles and the elders about this question.

verses.name: Acts 15:3
verses.text: So, being sent on their way by the church, they passed through both Phoenicia and Samaria, describing in detail the conversion of the Gentiles, and brought great joy to all the brothers.

verses.name: Acts 15:4
verses.text: When they came to Jerusalem, they were welcomed by the church and the apostles and the elders, and they declared all that God had done with them.

verses.name: Acts 15:5
verses.text: But some believers who belonged to the party of the Pharisees rose up and said, "It is necessary to circumcise them and to order them to keep the law of Moses."

verses.name: Acts 15:6
verses.text: The apostles and the elders were gathered together to consider this matter.

verses.name: Acts 15:7
verses.text: And after there had been much debate, Peter stood up and said to them, "Brothers, you know that in the early days God made a choice among you, that by my mouth the Gentiles should hear the word of the gospel and believe.

verses.name: Acts 15:8
verses.text: And God, who knows the heart, bore witness to them, by giving them the Holy Spirit just as he did to us,

verses.name: Acts 15:9
verses.text: and he made no distinction between us and them, having cleansed their hearts by faith.

verses.name: Acts 15:10
verses.text: Now, therefore, why are you putting God to the test by placing a yoke on the neck of the disciples that neither our fathers nor we have been able to bear?

verses.name: Acts 15:11
verses.text: But we believe that we will be saved through the grace of the Lord Jesus, just as they will."

verses.name: Acts 15:12
verses.text: And all the assembly fell silent, and they listened to Barnabas and Paul as they related what signs and wonders God had done through them among the Gentiles.

verses.name: Acts 15:13
verses.text: After they finished speaking, James replied, "Brothers, listen to me.

verses.name: Acts 15:14
verses.text: Simeon has related how God first visited the Gentiles, to take from them a people for his name.

verses.name: Acts 15:15
verses.text: And with this the words of the prophets agree, just as it is written,

verses.name: Acts 15:16
verses.text: "'After this I will return, and I will rebuild the tent of David that has fallen; I will rebuild its ruins, and I will restore it,

verses.name: Acts 15:17
verses.text: that the remnant of mankind may seek the Lord, and all the Gentiles who are called by my name, says the Lord, who makes these things

verses.name: Acts 15:18
verses.text: known from of old.'

verses.name: Acts 15:19
verses.text: Therefore my judgment is that we should not trouble those of the Gentiles who turn to God,

verses.name: Acts 15:20
verses.text: but should write to them to abstain from the things polluted by idols, and from sexual immorality, and from what has been strangled, and from blood.

verses.name: Acts 15:21
verses.text: For from ancient generations Moses has had in every city those who proclaim him, for he is read every Sabbath in the synagogues."

verses.name: Acts 15:22
verses.text: Then it seemed good to the apostles and the elders, with the whole church, to choose men from among them and send them to Antioch with Paul and Barnabas. They sent Judas called Barsabbas, and Silas, leading men among the brothers,

verses.name: Acts 15:23
verses.text: with the following letter: "The brothers, both the apostles and the elders, to the brothers who are of the Gentiles in Antioch and Syria and Cilicia, greetings.

verses.name: Acts 15:24
verses.text: Since we have heard that some persons have gone out from us and troubled you with words, unsettling your minds, although we gave them no instructions,

verses.name: Acts 15:25
verses.text: it has seemed good to us, having come to one accord, to choose men and send them to you with our beloved Barnabas and Paul,

verses.name: Acts 15:26
verses.text: men who have risked their lives for the sake of our Lord Jesus Christ.

verses.name: Acts 15:27
verses.text: We have therefore sent Judas and Silas, who themselves will tell you the same things by word of mouth.

verses.name: Acts 15:28
verses.text: For it has seemed good to the Holy Spirit and to us to lay on you no greater burden than these requirements:

verses.name: Acts 15:29
verses.text: that you abstain from what has been sacrificed to idols, and from blood, and from what has been strangled, and from sexual immorality. If you keep yourselves from these, you will do well. Farewell."

verses.name: Acts 15:30
verses.text: So when they were sent off, they went down to Antioch, and having gathered the congregation together, they delivered the letter.

verses.name: Acts 15:31
verses.text: And when they had read it, they rejoiced because of its encouragement.

verses.name: Acts 15:32
verses.text: And Judas and Silas, who were themselves prophets, encouraged and strengthened the brothers with many words.

verses.name: Acts 15:33
verses.text: And after they had spent some time, they were sent off in peace by the brothers to those who had sent them.

verses.name: Acts 15:35
verses.text: But Paul and Barnabas remained in Antioch, teaching and preaching the word of the Lord, with many others also.

verses.name: Acts 15:36
verses.text: And after some days Paul said to Barnabas, "Let us return and visit the brothers in every city where we proclaimed the word of the Lord, and see how they are."

verses.name: Acts 15:37
verses.text: Now Barnabas wanted to take with them John called Mark.

verses.name: Acts 15:38
verses.text: But Paul thought best not to take with them one who had withdrawn from them in Pamphylia and had not gone with them to the work.

verses.name: Acts 15:39
verses.text: And there arose a sharp disagreement, so that they separated from each other. Barnabas took Mark with him and sailed away to Cyprus,

verses.name: Acts 15:40
verses.text: but Paul chose Silas and departed, having been commended by the brothers to the grace of the Lord.

verses.name: Acts 15:41
verses.text: And he went through Syria and Cilicia, strengthening the churches.

verses.name: Acts 16:1
verses.text: Paul came also to Derbe and to Lystra. A disciple was there, named Timothy, the son of a Jewish woman who was a believer, but his father was a Greek.

verses.name: Acts 16:2
verses.text: He was well spoken of by the brothers at Lystra and Iconium.

verses.name: Acts 16:3
verses.text: Paul wanted Timothy to accompany him, and he took him and circumcised him because of the Jews who were in those places, for they all knew that his father was a Greek.

verses.name: Acts 16:4
verses.text: As they went on their way through the cities, they delivered to them for observance the decisions that had been reached by the apostles and elders who were in Jerusalem.

verses.name: Acts 16:5
verses.text: So the churches were strengthened in the faith, and they increased in numbers daily.

verses.name: Acts 16:6
verses.text: And they went through the region of Phrygia and Galatia, having been forbidden by the Holy Spirit to speak the word in Asia.

verses.name: Acts 16:7
verses.text: And when they had come up to Mysia, they attempted to go into Bithynia, but the Spirit of Jesus did not allow them.

verses.name: Acts 16:8
verses.text: So, passing by Mysia, they went down to Troas.

verses.name: Acts 16:9
verses.text: And a vision appeared to Paul in the night: a man of Macedonia was standing there, urging him and saying, "Come over to Macedonia and help us."

verses.name: Acts 16:10
verses.text: And when Paul had seen the vision, immediately we sought to go on into Macedonia, concluding that God had called us to preach the gospel to them.

verses.name: Acts 16:11
verses.text: So, setting sail from Troas, we made a direct voyage to Samothrace, and the following day to Neapolis,

verses.name: Acts 16:12
verses.text: and from there to Philippi, which is a leading city of the district of Macedonia and a Roman colony. We remained in this city some days.

verses.name: Acts 16:13
verses.text: And on the Sabbath day we went outside the gate to the riverside, where we supposed there was a place of prayer, and we sat down and spoke to the women who had come together.

verses.name: Acts 16:14
verses.text: One who heard us was a woman named Lydia, from the city of Thyatira, a seller of purple goods, who was a worshiper of God. The Lord opened her heart to pay attention to what was said by Paul.

verses.name: Acts 16:15
verses.text: And after she was baptized, and her household as well, she urged us, saying, "If you have judged me to be faithful to the Lord, come to my house and stay." And she prevailed upon us.

verses.name: Acts 16:16
verses.text: As we were going to the place of prayer, we were met by a slave girl who had a spirit of divination and brought her owners much gain by fortune-telling.

verses.name: Acts 16:17
verses.text: She followed Paul and us, crying out, "These men are servants of the Most High God, who proclaim to you the way of salvation."

verses.name: Acts 16:18
verses.text: And this she kept doing for many days. Paul, having become greatly annoyed, turned and said to the spirit, "I command you in the name of Jesus Christ to come out of her." And it came out that very hour.

verses.name: Acts 16:19
verses.text: But when her owners saw that their hope of gain was gone, they seized Paul and Silas and dragged them into the marketplace before the rulers.

verses.name: Acts 16:20
verses.text: And when they had brought them to the magistrates, they said, "These men are Jews, and they are disturbing our city.

verses.name: Acts 16:21
verses.text: They advocate customs that are not lawful for us as Romans to accept or practice."

verses.name: Acts 16:22
verses.text: The crowd joined in attacking them, and the magistrates tore the garments off them and gave orders to beat them with rods.

verses.name: Acts 16:23
verses.text: And when they had inflicted many blows upon them, they threw them into prison, ordering the jailer to keep them safely.

verses.name: Acts 16:24
verses.text: Having received this order, he put them into the inner prison and fastened their feet in the stocks.

verses.name: Acts 16:25
verses.text: About midnight Paul and Silas were praying and singing hymns to God, and the prisoners were listening to them,

verses.name: Acts 16:26
verses.text: and suddenly there was a great earthquake, so that the foundations of the prison were shaken. And immediately all the doors were opened, and everyone's bonds were unfastened.

verses.name: Acts 16:27
verses.text: When the jailer woke and saw that the prison doors were open, he drew his sword and was about to kill himself, supposing that the prisoners had escaped.

verses.name: Acts 16:28
verses.text: But Paul cried with a loud voice, "Do not harm yourself, for we are all here."

verses.name: Acts 16:29
verses.text: And the jailer called for lights and rushed in, and trembling with fear he fell down before Paul and Silas.

verses.name: Acts 16:30
verses.text: Then he brought them out and said, "Sirs, what must I do to be saved?"

verses.name: Acts 16:31
verses.text: And they said, "Believe in the Lord Jesus, and you will be saved, you and your household."

verses.name: Acts 16:32
verses.text: And they spoke the word of the Lord to him and to all who were in his house.

verses.name: Acts 16:33
verses.text: And he took them the same hour of the night and washed their wounds; and he was baptized at once, he and all his family.

verses.name: Acts 16:34
verses.text: Then he brought them up into his house and set food before them. And he rejoiced along with his entire household that he had believed in God.

verses.name: Acts 16:35
verses.text: But when it was day, the magistrates sent the police, saying, "Let those men go."

verses.name: Acts 16:36
verses.text: And the jailer reported these words to Paul, saying, "The magistrates have sent to let you go. Therefore come out now and go in peace."

verses.name: Acts 16:37
verses.text: But Paul said to them, "They have beaten us publicly, uncondemned, men who are Roman citizens, and have thrown us into prison; and do they now throw us out secretly? No! Let them come themselves and take us out."

verses.name: Acts 16:38
verses.text: The police reported these words to the magistrates, and they were afraid when they heard that they were Roman citizens.

verses.name: Acts 16:39
verses.text: So they came and apologized to them. And they took them out and asked them to leave the city.

verses.name: Acts 16:40
verses.text: So they went out of the prison and visited Lydia. And when they had seen the brothers, they encouraged them and departed.

verses.name: Acts 17:1
verses.text: Now when they had passed through Amphipolis and Apollonia, they came to Thessalonica, where there was a synagogue of the Jews.

verses.name: Acts 17:2
verses.text: And Paul went in, as was his custom, and on three Sabbath days he reasoned with them from the Scriptures,

verses.name: Acts 17:3
verses.text: explaining and proving that it was necessary for the Christ to suffer and to rise from the dead, and saying, "This Jesus, whom I proclaim to you, is the Christ."

verses.name: Acts 17:4
verses.text: And some of them were persuaded and joined Paul and Silas, as did a great many of the devout Greeks and not a few of the leading women.

verses.name: Acts 17:5
verses.text: But the Jews were jealous, and taking some wicked men of the rabble, they formed a mob, set the city in an uproar, and attacked the house of Jason, seeking to bring them out to the crowd.

verses.name: Acts 17:6
verses.text: And when they could not find them, they dragged Jason and some of the brothers before the city authorities, shouting, "These men who have turned the world upside down have come here also,

verses.name: Acts 17:7
verses.text: and Jason has received them, and they are all acting against the decrees of Caesar, saying that there is another king, Jesus."

verses.name: Acts 17:8
verses.text: And the people and the city authorities were disturbed when they heard these things.

verses.name: Acts 17:9
verses.text: And when they had taken money as security from Jason and the rest, they let them go.

verses.name: Acts 17:10
verses.text: The brothers immediately sent Paul and Silas away by night to Berea, and when they arrived they went into the Jewish synagogue.

verses.name: Acts 17:11
verses.text: Now these Jews were more noble than those in Thessalonica; they received the word with all eagerness, examining the Scriptures daily to see if these things were so.

verses.name: Acts 17:12
verses.text: Many of them therefore believed, with not a few Greek women of high standing as well as men.

verses.name: Acts 17:13
verses.text: But when the Jews from Thessalonica learned that the word of God was proclaimed by Paul at Berea also, they came there too, agitating and stirring up the crowds.

verses.name: Acts 17:14
verses.text: Then the brothers immediately sent Paul off on his way to the sea, but Silas and Timothy remained there.

verses.name: Acts 17:15
verses.text: Those who conducted Paul brought him as far as Athens, and after receiving a command for Silas and Timothy to come to him as soon as possible, they departed.

verses.name: Acts 17:16
verses.text: Now while Paul was waiting for them at Athens, his spirit was provoked within him as he saw that the city was full of idols.

verses.name: Acts 17:17
verses.text: So he reasoned in the synagogue with the Jews and the devout persons, and in the marketplace every day with those who happened to be there.

verses.name: Acts 17:18
verses.text: Some of the Epicurean and Stoic philosophers also conversed with him. And some said, "What does this babbler wish to say?" Others said, "He seems to be a preacher of foreign divinities"- because he was preaching Jesus and the resurrection.

verses.name: Acts 17:19
verses.text: And they took hold of him and brought him to the Areopagus, saying, "May we know what this new teaching is that you are presenting?

verses.name: Acts 17:20
verses.text: For you bring some strange things to our ears. We wish to know therefore what these things mean."

verses.name: Acts 17:21
verses.text: Now all the Athenians and the foreigners who lived there would spend their time in nothing except telling or hearing something new.

verses.name: Acts 17:22
verses.text: So Paul, standing in the midst of the Areopagus, said: "Men of Athens, I perceive that in every way you are very religious.

verses.name: Acts 17:23
verses.text: For as I passed along and observed the objects of your worship, I found also an altar with this inscription, 'To the unknown god.' What therefore you worship as unknown, this I proclaim to you.

verses.name: Acts 17:24
verses.text: The God who made the world and everything in it, being Lord of heaven and earth, does not live in temples made by man,

verses.name: Acts 17:25
verses.text: nor is he served by human hands, as though he needed anything, since he himself gives to all mankind life and breath and everything.

verses.name: Acts 17:26
verses.text: And he made from one man every nation of mankind to live on all the face of the earth, having determined allotted periods and the boundaries of their dwelling place,

verses.name: Acts 17:27
verses.text: that they should seek God, in the hope that they might feel their way toward him and find him. Yet he is actually not far from each one of us,

verses.name: Acts 17:28
verses.text: for "'In him we live and move and have our being'; as even some of your own poets have said, "' For we are indeed his offspring.'

verses.name: Acts 17:29
verses.text: Being then God's offspring, we ought not to think that the divine being is like gold or silver or stone, an image formed by the art and imagination of man.

verses.name: Acts 17:30
verses.text: The times of ignorance God overlooked, but now he commands all people everywhere to repent,

verses.name: Acts 17:31
verses.text: because he has fixed a day on which he will judge the world in righteousness by a man whom he has appointed; and of this he has given assurance to all by raising him from the dead."

verses.name: Acts 17:32
verses.text: Now when they heard of the resurrection of the dead, some mocked. But others said, "We will hear you again about this."

verses.name: Acts 17:33
verses.text: So Paul went out from their midst.

verses.name: Acts 17:34
verses.text: But some men joined him and believed, among them Dionysius the Areopagite and a woman named Damaris and others with them.

verses.name: Acts 18:1
verses.text: After this Paul left Athens and went to Corinth.

verses.name: Acts 18:2
verses.text: And he found a Jew named Aquila, a native of Pontus, recently come from Italy with his wife Priscilla, because Claudius had commanded all the Jews to leave Rome. And he went to see them,

verses.name: Acts 18:3
verses.text: and because he was of the same trade he stayed with them and worked, for they were tentmakers by trade.

verses.name: Acts 18:4
verses.text: And he reasoned in the synagogue every Sabbath, and tried to persuade Jews and Greeks.

verses.name: Acts 18:5
verses.text: When Silas and Timothy arrived from Macedonia, Paul was occupied with the word, testifying to the Jews that the Christ was Jesus.

verses.name: Acts 18:6
verses.text: And when they opposed and reviled him, he shook out his garments and said to them, "Your blood be on your own heads! I am innocent. From now on I will go to the Gentiles."

verses.name: Acts 18:7
verses.text: And he left there and went to the house of a man named Titius Justus, a worshiper of God. His house was next door to the synagogue.

verses.name: Acts 18:8
verses.text: Crispus, the ruler of the synagogue, believed in the Lord, together with his entire household. And many of the Corinthians hearing Paul believed and were baptized.

verses.name: Acts 18:9
verses.text: And the Lord said to Paul one night in a vision, "Do not be afraid, but go on speaking and do not be silent,

verses.name: Acts 18:10
verses.text: for I am with you, and no one will attack you to harm you, for I have many in this city who are my people."

verses.name: Acts 18:11
verses.text: And he stayed a year and six months, teaching the word of God among them.

verses.name: Acts 18:12
verses.text: But when Gallio was proconsul of Achaia, the Jews made a united attack on Paul and brought him before the tribunal,

verses.name: Acts 18:13
verses.text: saying, "This man is persuading people to worship God contrary to the law."

verses.name: Acts 18:14
verses.text: But when Paul was about to open his mouth, Gallio said to the Jews, "If it were a matter of wrongdoing or vicious crime, O Jews, I would have reason to accept your complaint.

verses.name: Acts 18:15
verses.text: But since it is a matter of questions about words and names and your own law, see to it yourselves. I refuse to be a judge of these things."

verses.name: Acts 18:16
verses.text: And he drove them from the tribunal.

verses.name: Acts 18:17
verses.text: And they all seized Sosthenes, the ruler of the synagogue, and beat him in front of the tribunal. But Gallio paid no attention to any of this.

verses.name: Acts 18:18
verses.text: After this, Paul stayed many days longer and then took leave of the brothers and set sail for Syria, and with him Priscilla and Aquila. At Cenchreae he had cut his hair, for he was under a vow.

verses.name: Acts 18:19
verses.text: And they came to Ephesus, and he left them there, but he himself went into the synagogue and reasoned with the Jews.

verses.name: Acts 18:20
verses.text: When they asked him to stay for a longer period, he declined.

verses.name: Acts 18:21
verses.text: But on taking leave of them he said, "I will return to you if God wills," and he set sail from Ephesus.

verses.name: Acts 18:22
verses.text: When he had landed at Caesarea, he went up and greeted the church, and then went down to Antioch.

verses.name: Acts 18:23
verses.text: After spending some time there, he departed and went from one place to the next through the region of Galatia and Phrygia, strengthening all the disciples.

verses.name: Acts 18:24
verses.text: Now a Jew named Apollos, a native of Alexandria, came to Ephesus. He was an eloquent man, competent in the Scriptures.

verses.name: Acts 18:25
verses.text: He had been instructed in the way of the Lord. And being fervent in spirit, he spoke and taught accurately the things concerning Jesus, though he knew only the baptism of John.

verses.name: Acts 18:26
verses.text: He began to speak boldly in the synagogue, but when Priscilla and Aquila heard him, they took him and explained to him the way of God more accurately.

verses.name: Acts 18:27
verses.text: And when he wished to cross to Achaia, the brothers encouraged him and wrote to the disciples to welcome him. When he arrived, he greatly helped those who through grace had believed,

verses.name: Acts 18:28
verses.text: for he powerfully refuted the Jews in public, showing by the Scriptures that the Christ was Jesus.

verses.name: Acts 19:1
verses.text: And it happened that while Apollos was at Corinth, Paul passed through the inland country and came to Ephesus. There he found some disciples.

verses.name: Acts 19:2
verses.text: And he said to them, "Did you receive the Holy Spirit when you believed?" And they said, "No, we have not even heard that there is a Holy Spirit."

verses.name: Acts 19:3
verses.text: And he said, "Into what then were you baptized?" They said, "Into John's baptism."

verses.name: Acts 19:4
verses.text: And Paul said, "John baptized with the baptism of repentance, telling the people to believe in the one who was to come after him, that is, Jesus."

verses.name: Acts 19:5
verses.text: On hearing this, they were baptized in the name of the Lord Jesus.

verses.name: Acts 19:6
verses.text: And when Paul had laid his hands on them, the Holy Spirit came on them, and they began speaking in tongues and prophesying.

verses.name: Acts 19:7
verses.text: There were about twelve men in all.

verses.name: Acts 19:8
verses.text: And he entered the synagogue and for three months spoke boldly, reasoning and persuading them about the kingdom of God.

verses.name: Acts 19:9
verses.text: But when some became stubborn and continued in unbelief, speaking evil of the Way before the congregation, he withdrew from them and took the disciples with him, reasoning daily in the hall of Tyrannus.

verses.name: Acts 19:10
verses.text: This continued for two years, so that all the residents of Asia heard the word of the Lord, both Jews and Greeks.

verses.name: Acts 19:11
verses.text: And God was doing extraordinary miracles by the hands of Paul,

verses.name: Acts 19:12
verses.text: so that even handkerchiefs or aprons that had touched his skin were carried away to the sick, and their diseases left them and the evil spirits came out of them.

verses.name: Acts 19:13
verses.text: Then some of the itinerant Jewish exorcists undertook to invoke the name of the Lord Jesus over those who had evil spirits, saying, "I adjure you by the Jesus, whom Paul proclaims."

verses.name: Acts 19:14
verses.text: Seven sons of a Jewish high priest named Sceva were doing this.

verses.name: Acts 19:15
verses.text: But the evil spirit answered them, "Jesus I know, and Paul I recognize, but who are you?"

verses.name: Acts 19:16
verses.text: And the man in whom was the evil spirit leaped on them, mastered all of them and overpowered them, so that they fled out of that house naked and wounded.

verses.name: Acts 19:17
verses.text: And this became known to all the residents of Ephesus, both Jews and Greeks. And fear fell upon them all, and the name of the Lord Jesus was extolled.

verses.name: Acts 19:18
verses.text: Also many of those who were now believers came, confessing and divulging their practices.

verses.name: Acts 19:19
verses.text: And a number of those who had practiced magic arts brought their books together and burned them in the sight of all. And they counted the value of them and found it came to fifty thousand pieces of silver.

verses.name: Acts 19:20
verses.text: So the word of the Lord continued to increase and prevail mightily.

verses.name: Acts 19:21
verses.text: Now after these events Paul resolved in the Spirit to pass through Macedonia and Achaia and go to Jerusalem, saying, "After I have been there, I must also see Rome."

verses.name: Acts 19:22
verses.text: And having sent into Macedonia two of his helpers, Timothy and Erastus, he himself stayed in Asia for a while.

verses.name: Acts 19:23
verses.text: About that time there arose no little disturbance concerning the Way.

verses.name: Acts 19:24
verses.text: For a man named Demetrius, a silversmith, who made silver shrines of Artemis, brought no little business to the craftsmen.

verses.name: Acts 19:25
verses.text: These he gathered together, with the workmen in similar trades, and said, "Men, you know that from this business we have our wealth.

verses.name: Acts 19:26
verses.text: And you see and hear that not only in Ephesus but in almost all of Asia this Paul has persuaded and turned away a great many people, saying that gods made with hands are not gods.

verses.name: Acts 19:27
verses.text: And there is danger not only that this trade of ours may come into disrepute but also that the temple of the great goddess Artemis may be counted as nothing, and that she may even be deposed from her magnificence, she whom all Asia and the world worship."

verses.name: Acts 19:28
verses.text: When they heard this they were enraged and were crying out, "Great is Artemis of the Ephesians!"

verses.name: Acts 19:29
verses.text: So the city was filled with the confusion, and they rushed together into the theater, dragging with them Gaius and Aristarchus, Macedonians who were Paul's companions in travel.

verses.name: Acts 19:30
verses.text: But when Paul wished to go in among the crowd, the disciples would not let him.

verses.name: Acts 19:31
verses.text: And even some of the Asiarchs, who were friends of his, sent to him and were urging him not to venture into the theater.

verses.name: Acts 19:32
verses.text: Now some cried out one thing, some another, for the assembly was in confusion, and most of them did not know why they had come together.

verses.name: Acts 19:33
verses.text: Some of the crowd prompted Alexander, whom the Jews had put forward. And Alexander, motioning with his hand, wanted to make a defense to the crowd.

verses.name: Acts 19:34
verses.text: But when they recognized that he was a Jew, for about two hours they all cried out with one voice, "Great is Artemis of the Ephesians!"

verses.name: Acts 19:35
verses.text: And when the town clerk had quieted the crowd, he said, "Men of Ephesus, who is there who does not know that the city of the Ephesians is temple keeper of the great Artemis, and of the sacred stone that fell from the sky?

verses.name: Acts 19:36
verses.text: Seeing then that these things cannot be denied, you ought to be quiet and do nothing rash.

verses.name: Acts 19:37
verses.text: For you have brought these men here who are neither sacrilegious nor blasphemers of our goddess.

verses.name: Acts 19:38
verses.text: If therefore Demetrius and the craftsmen with him have a complaint against anyone, the courts are open, and there are proconsuls. Let them bring charges against one another.

verses.name: Acts 19:39
verses.text: But if you seek anything further, it shall be settled in the regular assembly.

verses.name: Acts 19:40
verses.text: For we really are in danger of being charged with rioting today, since there is no cause that we can give to justify this commotion."

verses.name: Acts 19:41
verses.text: And when he had said these things, he dismissed the assembly.

verses.name: Acts 20:1
verses.text: After the uproar ceased, Paul sent for the disciples, and after encouraging them, he said farewell and departed for Macedonia.

verses.name: Acts 20:2
verses.text: When he had gone through those regions and had given them much encouragement, he came to Greece.

verses.name: Acts 20:3
verses.text: There he spent three months, and when a plot was made against him by the Jews as he was about to set sail for Syria, he decided to return through Macedonia.

verses.name: Acts 20:4
verses.text: Sopater of Berea, the son of Pyrrhus from Berea, accompanied him; and of the Thessalonians, Aristarchus and Secundus; and Gaius of Derbe, and Timothy; and the Asians, Tychicus and Trophimus.

verses.name: Acts 20:5
verses.text: These went on ahead and were waiting for us at Troas,

verses.name: Acts 20:6
verses.text: but we sailed away from Philippi after the days of Unleavened Bread, and in five days we came to them at Troas, where we stayed for seven days.

verses.name: Acts 20:7
verses.text: On the first day of the week, when we were gathered together to break bread, Paul talked with them, intending to depart on the next day, and he prolonged his speech until midnight.

verses.name: Acts 20:8
verses.text: There were many lamps in the upper room where we were gathered.

verses.name: Acts 20:9
verses.text: And a young man named Eutychus, sitting at the window, sank into a deep sleep as Paul talked still longer. And being overcome by sleep, he fell down from the third story and was taken up dead.

verses.name: Acts 20:10
verses.text: But Paul went down and bent over him, and taking him in his arms, said, "Do not be alarmed, for his life is in him."

verses.name: Acts 20:11
verses.text: And when Paul had gone up and had broken bread and eaten, he conversed with them a long while, until daybreak, and so departed.

verses.name: Acts 20:12
verses.text: And they took the youth away alive, and were not a little comforted.

verses.name: Acts 20:13
verses.text: But going ahead to the ship, we set sail for Assos, intending to take Paul aboard there, for so he had arranged, intending himself to go by land.

verses.name: Acts 20:14
verses.text: And when he met us at Assos, we took him on board and went to Mitylene.

verses.name: Acts 20:15
verses.text: And sailing from there we came the following day opposite Chios; the next day we touched at Samos; and the day after that we went to Miletus.

verses.name: Acts 20:16
verses.text: For Paul had decided to sail past Ephesus, so that he might not have to spend time in Asia, for he was hastening to be at Jerusalem, if possible, on the day of Pentecost.

verses.name: Acts 20:17
verses.text: Now from Miletus he sent to Ephesus and called the elders of the church to come to him.

verses.name: Acts 20:18
verses.text: And when they came to him, he said to them: "You yourselves know how I lived among you the whole time from the first day that I set foot in Asia,

verses.name: Acts 20:19
verses.text: serving the Lord with all humility and with tears and with trials that happened to me through the plots of the Jews;

verses.name: Acts 20:20
verses.text: how I did not shrink from declaring to you anything that was profitable, and teaching you in public and from house to house,

verses.name: Acts 20:21
verses.text: testifying both to Jews and to Greeks of repentance toward God and of faith in our Lord Jesus Christ.

verses.name: Acts 20:22
verses.text: And now, behold, I am going to Jerusalem, constrained by the Spirit, not knowing what will happen to me there,

verses.name: Acts 20:23
verses.text: except that the Holy Spirit testifies to me in every city that imprisonment and afflictions await me.

verses.name: Acts 20:24
verses.text: But I do not account my life of any value nor as precious to myself, if only I may finish my course and the ministry that I received from the Lord Jesus, to testify to the gospel of the grace of God.

verses.name: Acts 20:25
verses.text: And now, behold, I know that none of you among whom I have gone about proclaiming the kingdom will see my face again.

verses.name: Acts 20:26
verses.text: Therefore I testify to you this day that I am innocent of the blood of all of you,

verses.name: Acts 20:27
verses.text: for I did not shrink from declaring to you the whole counsel of God.

verses.name: Acts 20:28
verses.text: Pay careful attention to yourselves and to all the flock, in which the Holy Spirit has made you overseers, to care for the church of God, which he obtained with his own blood.

verses.name: Acts 20:29
verses.text: I know that after my departure fierce wolves will come in among you, not sparing the flock;

verses.name: Acts 20:30
verses.text: and from among your own selves will arise men speaking twisted things, to draw away the disciples after them.

verses.name: Acts 20:31
verses.text: Therefore be alert, remembering that for three years I did not cease night or day to admonish everyone with tears.

verses.name: Acts 20:32
verses.text: And now I commend you to God and to the word of his grace, which is able to build you up and to give you the inheritance among all those who are sanctified.

verses.name: Acts 20:33
verses.text: I coveted no one's silver or gold or apparel.

verses.name: Acts 20:34
verses.text: You yourselves know that these hands ministered to my necessities and to those who were with me.

verses.name: Acts 20:35
verses.text: In all things I have shown you that by working hard in this way we must help the weak and remember the words of the Lord Jesus, how he himself said, 'It is more blessed to give than to receive.'"

verses.name: Acts 20:36
verses.text: And when he had said these things, he knelt down and prayed with them all.

verses.name: Acts 20:37
verses.text: And there was much weeping on the part of all; they embraced Paul and kissed him,

verses.name: Acts 20:38
verses.text: being sorrowful most of all because of the word he had spoken, that they would not see his face again. And they accompanied him to the ship.

verses.name: Acts 21:1
verses.text: And when we had parted from them and set sail, we came by a straight course to Cos, and the next day to Rhodes, and from there to Patara.

verses.name: Acts 21:2
verses.text: And having found a ship crossing to Phoenicia, we went aboard and set sail.

verses.name: Acts 21:3
verses.text: When we had come in sight of Cyprus, leaving it on the left we sailed to Syria and landed at Tyre, for there the ship was to unload its cargo.

verses.name: Acts 21:4
verses.text: And having sought out the disciples, we stayed there for seven days. And through the Spirit they were telling Paul not to go on to Jerusalem.

verses.name: Acts 21:5
verses.text: When our days there were ended, we departed and went on our journey, and they all, with wives and children, accompanied us until we were outside the city. And kneeling down on the beach, we prayed

verses.name: Acts 21:6
verses.text: and said farewell to one another. Then we went on board the ship, and they returned home.

verses.name: Acts 21:7
verses.text: When we had finished the voyage from Tyre, we arrived at Ptolemais, and we greeted the brothers and stayed with them for one day.

verses.name: Acts 21:8
verses.text: On the next day we departed and came to Caesarea, and we entered the house of Philip the evangelist, who was one of the seven, and stayed with him.

verses.name: Acts 21:9
verses.text: He had four unmarried daughters, who prophesied.

verses.name: Acts 21:10
verses.text: While we were staying for many days, a prophet named Agabus came down from Judea.

verses.name: Acts 21:11
verses.text: And coming to us, he took Paul's belt and bound his own feet and hands and said, "Thus says the Holy Spirit, 'This is how the Jews at Jerusalem will bind the man who owns this belt and deliver him into the hands of the Gentiles.'"

verses.name: Acts 21:12
verses.text: When we heard this, we and the people there urged him not to go up to Jerusalem.

verses.name: Acts 21:13
verses.text: Then Paul answered, "What are you doing, weeping and breaking my heart? For I am ready not only to be imprisoned but even to die in Jerusalem for the name of the Lord Jesus."

verses.name: Acts 21:14
verses.text: And since he would not be persuaded, we ceased and said, "Let the will of the Lord be done."

verses.name: Acts 21:15
verses.text: After these days we got ready and went up to Jerusalem.

verses.name: Acts 21:16
verses.text: And some of the disciples from Caesarea went with us, bringing us to the house of Mnason of Cyprus, an early disciple, with whom we should lodge.

verses.name: Acts 21:17
verses.text: When we had come to Jerusalem, the brothers received us gladly.

verses.name: Acts 21:18
verses.text: On the following day Paul went in with us to James, and all the elders were present.

verses.name: Acts 21:19
verses.text: After greeting them, he related one by one the things that God had done among the Gentiles through his ministry.

verses.name: Acts 21:20
verses.text: And when they heard it, they glorified God. And they said to him, "You see, brother, how many thousands there are among the Jews of those who have believed. They are all zealous for the law,

verses.name: Acts 21:21
verses.text: and they have been told about you that you teach all the Jews who are among the Gentiles to forsake Moses, telling them not to circumcise their children or walk according to our customs.

verses.name: Acts 21:22
verses.text: What then is to be done? They will certainly hear that you have come.

verses.name: Acts 21:23
verses.text: Do therefore what we tell you. We have four men who are under a vow;

verses.name: Acts 21:24
verses.text: take these men and purify yourself along with them and pay their expenses, so that they may shave their heads. Thus all will know that there is nothing in what they have been told about you, but that you yourself also live in observance of the law.

verses.name: Acts 21:25
verses.text: But as for the Gentiles who have believed, we have sent a letter with our judgment that they should abstain from what has been sacrificed to idols, and from blood, and from what has been strangled, and from sexual immorality."

verses.name: Acts 21:26
verses.text: Then Paul took the men, and the next day he purified himself along with them and went into the temple, giving notice when the days of purification would be fulfilled and the offering presented for each one of them.

verses.name: Acts 21:27
verses.text: When the seven days were almost completed, the Jews from Asia, seeing him in the temple, stirred up the whole crowd and laid hands on him,

verses.name: Acts 21:28
verses.text: crying out, "Men of Israel, help! This is the man who is teaching everyone everywhere against the people and the law and this place. Moreover, he even brought Greeks into the temple and has defiled this holy place."

verses.name: Acts 21:29
verses.text: For they had previously seen Trophimus the Ephesian with him in the city, and they supposed that Paul had brought him into the temple.

verses.name: Acts 21:30
verses.text: Then all the city was stirred up, and the people ran together. They seized Paul and dragged him out of the temple, and at once the gates were shut.

verses.name: Acts 21:31
verses.text: And as they were seeking to kill him, word came to the tribune of the cohort that all Jerusalem was in confusion.

verses.name: Acts 21:32
verses.text: He at once took soldiers and centurions and ran down to them. And when they saw the tribune and the soldiers, they stopped beating Paul.

verses.name: Acts 21:33
verses.text: Then the tribune came up and arrested him and ordered him to be bound with two chains. He inquired who he was and what he had done.

verses.name: Acts 21:34
verses.text: Some in the crowd were shouting one thing, some another. And as he could not learn the facts because of the uproar, he ordered him to be brought into the barracks.

verses.name: Acts 21:35
verses.text: And when he came to the steps, he was actually carried by the soldiers because of the violence of the crowd,

verses.name: Acts 21:36
verses.text: for the mob of the people followed, crying out, "Away with him!"

verses.name: Acts 21:37
verses.text: As Paul was about to be brought into the barracks, he said to the tribune, "May I say something to you?" And he said, "Do you know Greek?

verses.name: Acts 21:38
verses.text: Are you not the Egyptian, then, who recently stirred up a revolt and led the four thousand men of the Assassins out into the wilderness?"

verses.name: Acts 21:39
verses.text: Paul replied, "I am a Jew, from Tarsus in Cilicia, a citizen of no obscure city. I beg you, permit me to speak to the people."

verses.name: Acts 21:40
verses.text: And when he had given him permission, Paul, standing on the steps, motioned with his hand to the people. And when there was a great hush, he addressed them in the Hebrew language, saying:

verses.name: Acts 22:1
verses.text: "Brothers and fathers, hear the defense that I now make before you."

verses.name: Acts 22:2
verses.text: And when they heard that he was addressing them in the Hebrew language, they became even more quiet. And he said:

verses.name: Acts 22:3
verses.text: "I am a Jew, born in Tarsus in Cilicia, but brought up in this city, educated at the feet of Gamaliel according to the strict manner of the law of our fathers, being zealous for God as all of you are this day.

verses.name: Acts 22:4
verses.text: I persecuted this Way to the death, binding and delivering to prison both men and women,

verses.name: Acts 22:5
verses.text: as the high priest and the whole council of elders can bear me witness. From them I received letters to the brothers, and I journeyed toward Damascus to take those also who were there and bring them in bonds to Jerusalem to be punished.

verses.name: Acts 22:6
verses.text: "As I was on my way and drew near to Damascus, about noon a great light from heaven suddenly shone around me.

verses.name: Acts 22:7
verses.text: And I fell to the ground and heard a voice saying to me, 'Saul, Saul, why are you persecuting me?'

verses.name: Acts 22:8
verses.text: And I answered, 'Who are you, Lord?' And he said to me, 'I am Jesus of Nazareth, whom you are persecuting.'

verses.name: Acts 22:9
verses.text: Now those who were with me saw the light but did not understand the voice of the one who was speaking to me.

verses.name: Acts 22:10
verses.text: And I said, 'What shall I do, Lord?' And the Lord said to me, 'Rise, and go into Damascus, and there you will be told all that is appointed for you to do.'

verses.name: Acts 22:11
verses.text: And since I could not see because of the brightness of that light, I was led by the hand by those who were with me, and came into Damascus.

verses.name: Acts 22:12
verses.text: "And one Ananias, a devout man according to the law, well spoken of by all the Jews who lived there,

verses.name: Acts 22:13
verses.text: came to me, and standing by me said to me, 'Brother Saul, receive your sight.' And at that very hour I received my sight and saw him.

verses.name: Acts 22:14
verses.text: And he said, 'The God of our fathers appointed you to know his will, to see the Righteous One and to hear a voice from his mouth;

verses.name: Acts 22:15
verses.text: for you will be a witness for him to everyone of what you have seen and heard.

verses.name: Acts 22:16
verses.text: And now why do you wait? Rise and be baptized and wash away your sins, calling on his name.'

verses.name: Acts 22:17
verses.text: "When I had returned to Jerusalem and was praying in the temple, I fell into a trance

verses.name: Acts 22:18
verses.text: and saw him saying to me, 'Make haste and get out of Jerusalem quickly, because they will not accept your testimony about me.'

verses.name: Acts 22:19
verses.text: And I said, 'Lord, they themselves know that in one synagogue after another I imprisoned and beat those who believed in you.

verses.name: Acts 22:20
verses.text: And when the blood of Stephen your witness was being shed, I myself was standing by and approving and watching over the garments of those who killed him.'

verses.name: Acts 22:21
verses.text: And he said to me, 'Go, for I will send you far away to the Gentiles.'"

verses.name: Acts 22:22
verses.text: Up to this word they listened to him. Then they raised their voices and said, "Away with such a fellow from the earth! For he should not be allowed to live."

verses.name: Acts 22:23
verses.text: And as they were shouting and throwing off their cloaks and flinging dust into the air,

verses.name: Acts 22:24
verses.text: the tribune ordered him to be brought into the barracks, saying that he should be examined by flogging, to find out why they were shouting against him like this.

verses.name: Acts 22:25
verses.text: But when they had stretched him out for the whips, Paul said to the centurion who was standing by, "Is it lawful for you to flog a man who is a Roman citizen and uncondemned?"

verses.name: Acts 22:26
verses.text: When the centurion heard this, he went to the tribune and said to him, "What are you about to do? For this man is a Roman citizen."

verses.name: Acts 22:27
verses.text: So the tribune came and said to him, "Tell me, are you a Roman citizen?" And he said, "Yes."

verses.name: Acts 22:28
verses.text: The tribune answered, "I bought this citizenship for a large sum." Paul said, "But I am a citizen by birth."

verses.name: Acts 22:29
verses.text: So those who were about to examine him withdrew from him immediately, and the tribune also was afraid, for he realized that Paul was a Roman citizen and that he had bound him.

verses.name: Acts 22:30
verses.text: But on the next day, desiring to know the real reason why he was being accused by the Jews, he unbound him and commanded the chief priests and all the council to meet, and he brought Paul down and set him before them.

verses.name: Acts 23:1
verses.text: And looking intently at the council, Paul said, "Brothers, I have lived my life before God in all good conscience up to this day."

verses.name: Acts 23:2
verses.text: And the high priest Ananias commanded those who stood by him to strike him on the mouth.

verses.name: Acts 23:3
verses.text: Then Paul said to him, "God is going to strike you, you whitewashed wall! Are you sitting to judge me according to the law, and yet contrary to the law you order me to be struck?"

verses.name: Acts 23:4
verses.text: Those who stood by said, "Would you revile God's high priest?"

verses.name: Acts 23:5
verses.text: And Paul said, "I did not know, brothers, that he was the high priest, for it is written, 'You shall not speak evil of a ruler of your people.'"

verses.name: Acts 23:6
verses.text: Now when Paul perceived that one part were Sadducees and the other Pharisees, he cried out in the council, "Brothers, I am a Pharisee, a son of Pharisees. It is with respect to the hope and the resurrection of the dead that I am on trial."

verses.name: Acts 23:7
verses.text: And when he had said this, a dissension arose between the Pharisees and the Sadducees, and the assembly was divided.

verses.name: Acts 23:8
verses.text: For the Sadducees say that there is no resurrection, nor angel, nor spirit, but the Pharisees acknowledge them all.

verses.name: Acts 23:9
verses.text: Then a great clamor arose, and some of the scribes of the Pharisees' party stood up and contended sharply, "We find nothing wrong in this man. What if a spirit or an angel spoke to him?"

verses.name: Acts 23:10
verses.text: And when the dissension became violent, the tribune, afraid that Paul would be torn to pieces by them, commanded the soldiers to go down and take him away from among them by force and bring him into the barracks.

verses.name: Acts 23:11
verses.text: The following night the Lord stood by him and said, "Take courage, for as you have testified to the facts about me in Jerusalem, so you must testify also in Rome."

verses.name: Acts 23:12
verses.text: When it was day, the Jews made a plot and bound themselves by an oath neither to eat nor drink till they had killed Paul.

verses.name: Acts 23:13
verses.text: There were more than forty who made this conspiracy.

verses.name: Acts 23:14
verses.text: They went to the chief priests and elders and said, "We have strictly bound ourselves by an oath to taste no food till we have killed Paul.

verses.name: Acts 23:15
verses.text: Now therefore you, along with the council, give notice to the tribune to bring him down to you, as though you were going to determine his case more exactly. And we are ready to kill him before he comes near."

verses.name: Acts 23:16
verses.text: Now the son of Paul's sister heard of their ambush, so he went and entered the barracks and told Paul.

verses.name: Acts 23:17
verses.text: Paul called one of the centurions and said, "Take this young man to the tribune, for he has something to tell him."

verses.name: Acts 23:18
verses.text: So he took him and brought him to the tribune and said, "Paul the prisoner called me and asked me to bring this young man to you, as he has something to say to you."

verses.name: Acts 23:19
verses.text: The tribune took him by the hand, and going aside asked him privately, "What is it that you have to tell me?"

verses.name: Acts 23:20
verses.text: And he said, "The Jews have agreed to ask you to bring Paul down to the council tomorrow, as though they were going to inquire somewhat more closely about him.

verses.name: Acts 23:21
verses.text: But do not be persuaded by them, for more than forty of their men are lying in ambush for him, who have bound themselves by an oath neither to eat nor drink till they have killed him. And now they are ready, waiting for your consent."

verses.name: Acts 23:22
verses.text: So the tribune dismissed the young man, charging him, "Tell no one that you have informed me of these things."

verses.name: Acts 23:23
verses.text: Then he called two of the centurions and said, "Get ready two hundred soldiers, with seventy horsemen and two hundred spearmen to go as far as Caesarea at the third hour of the night.

verses.name: Acts 23:24
verses.text: Also provide mounts for Paul to ride and bring him safely to Felix the governor."

verses.name: Acts 23:25
verses.text: And he wrote a letter to this effect:

verses.name: Acts 23:26
verses.text: "Claudius Lysias, to his Excellency the governor Felix, greetings.

verses.name: Acts 23:27
verses.text: This man was seized by the Jews and was about to be killed by them when I came upon them with the soldiers and rescued him, having learned that he was a Roman citizen.

verses.name: Acts 23:28
verses.text: And desiring to know the charge for which they were accusing him, I brought him down to their council.

verses.name: Acts 23:29
verses.text: I found that he was being accused about questions of their law, but charged with nothing deserving death or imprisonment.

verses.name: Acts 23:30
verses.text: And when it was disclosed to me that there would be a plot against the man, I sent him to you at once, ordering his accusers also to state before you what they have against him."

verses.name: Acts 23:31
verses.text: So the soldiers, according to their instructions, took Paul and brought him by night to Antipatris.

verses.name: Acts 23:32
verses.text: And on the next day they returned to the barracks, letting the horsemen go on with him.

verses.name: Acts 23:33
verses.text: When they had come to Caesarea and delivered the letter to the governor, they presented Paul also before him.

verses.name: Acts 23:34
verses.text: On reading the letter, he asked what province he was from. And when he learned that he was from Cilicia,

verses.name: Acts 23:35
verses.text: he said, "I will give you a hearing when your accusers arrive." And he commanded him to be guarded in Herod's praetorium.

verses.name: Acts 24:1
verses.text: And after five days the high priest Ananias came down with some elders and a spokesman, one Tertullus. They laid before the governor their case against Paul.

verses.name: Acts 24:2
verses.text: And when he had been summoned, Tertullus began to accuse him, saying: "Since through you we enjoy much peace, and since by your foresight, most excellent Felix, reforms are being made for this nation,

verses.name: Acts 24:3
verses.text: in every way and everywhere we accept this with all gratitude.

verses.name: Acts 24:4
verses.text: But, to detain you no further, I beg you in your kindness to hear us briefly.

verses.name: Acts 24:5
verses.text: For we have found this man a plague, one who stirs up riots among all the Jews throughout the world and is a ringleader of the sect of the Nazarenes.

verses.name: Acts 24:6
verses.text: He even tried to profane the temple, but we seized him.

verses.name: Acts 24:8
verses.text: By examining him yourself you will be able to find out from him about everything of which we accuse him."

verses.name: Acts 24:9
verses.text: The Jews also joined in the charge, affirming that all these things were so.

verses.name: Acts 24:10
verses.text: And when the governor had nodded to him to speak, Paul replied: "Knowing that for many years you have been a judge over this nation, I cheerfully make my defense.

verses.name: Acts 24:11
verses.text: You can verify that it is not more than twelve days since I went up to worship in Jerusalem,

verses.name: Acts 24:12
verses.text: and they did not find me disputing with anyone or stirring up a crowd, either in the temple or in the synagogues or in the city.

verses.name: Acts 24:13
verses.text: Neither can they prove to you what they now bring up against me.

verses.name: Acts 24:14
verses.text: But this I confess to you, that according to the Way, which they call a sect, I worship the God of our fathers, believing everything laid down by the Law and written in the Prophets,

verses.name: Acts 24:15
verses.text: having a hope in God, which these men themselves accept, that there will be a resurrection of both the just and the unjust.

verses.name: Acts 24:16
verses.text: So I always take pains to have a clear conscience toward both God and man.

verses.name: Acts 24:17
verses.text: Now after several years I came to bring alms to my nation and to present offerings.

verses.name: Acts 24:18
verses.text: While I was doing this, they found me purified in the temple, without any crowd or tumult. But some Jews from Asia-

verses.name: Acts 24:19
verses.text: they ought to be here before you and to make an accusation, should they have anything against me.

verses.name: Acts 24:20
verses.text: Or else let these men themselves say what wrongdoing they found when I stood before the council,

verses.name: Acts 24:21
verses.text: other than this one thing that I cried out while standing among them: 'It is with respect to the resurrection of the dead that I am on trial before you this day.'"

verses.name: Acts 24:22
verses.text: But Felix, having a rather accurate knowledge of the Way, put them off, saying, "When Lysias the tribune comes down, I will decide your case."

verses.name: Acts 24:23
verses.text: Then he gave orders to the centurion that he should be kept in custody but have some liberty, and that none of his friends should be prevented from attending to his needs.

verses.name: Acts 24:24
verses.text: After some days Felix came with his wife Drusilla, who was Jewish, and he sent for Paul and heard him speak about faith in Christ Jesus.

verses.name: Acts 24:25
verses.text: And as he reasoned about righteousness and self-control and the coming judgment, Felix was alarmed and said, "Go away for the present. When I get an opportunity I will summon you."

verses.name: Acts 24:26
verses.text: At the same time he hoped that money would be given him by Paul. So he sent for him often and conversed with him.

verses.name: Acts 24:27
verses.text: When two years had elapsed, Felix was succeeded by Porcius Festus. And desiring to do the Jews a favor, Felix left Paul in prison.

verses.name: Acts 25:1
verses.text: Now three days after Festus had arrived in the province, he went up to Jerusalem from Caesarea.

verses.name: Acts 25:2
verses.text: And the chief priests and the principal men of the Jews laid out their case against Paul, and they urged him,

verses.name: Acts 25:3
verses.text: asking as a favor against Paul that he summon him to Jerusalem- because they were planning an ambush to kill him on the way.

verses.name: Acts 25:4
verses.text: Festus replied that Paul was being kept at Caesarea and that he himself intended to go there shortly.

verses.name: Acts 25:5
verses.text: "So," said he, "let the men of authority among you go down with me, and if there is anything wrong about the man, let them bring charges against him."

verses.name: Acts 25:6
verses.text: After he stayed among them not more than eight or ten days, he went down to Caesarea. And the next day he took his seat on the tribunal and ordered Paul to be brought.

verses.name: Acts 25:7
verses.text: When he had arrived, the Jews who had come down from Jerusalem stood around him, bringing many and serious charges against him that they could not prove.

verses.name: Acts 25:8
verses.text: Paul argued in his defense, "Neither against the law of the Jews, nor against the temple, nor against Caesar have I committed any offense."

verses.name: Acts 25:9
verses.text: But Festus, wishing to do the Jews a favor, said to Paul, "Do you wish to go up to Jerusalem and there be tried on these charges before me?"

verses.name: Acts 25:10
verses.text: But Paul said, "I am standing before Caesar's tribunal, where I ought to be tried. To the Jews I have done no wrong, as you yourselves know very well.

verses.name: Acts 25:11
verses.text: If then I am a wrongdoer and have committed anything for which I deserve to die, I do not seek to escape death. But if there is nothing to their charges against me, no one can give me up to them. I appeal to Caesar."

verses.name: Acts 25:12
verses.text: Then Festus, when he had conferred with his council, answered, "To Caesar you have appealed; to Caesar you shall go."

verses.name: Acts 25:13
verses.text: Now when some days had passed, Agrippa the king and Bernice arrived at Caesarea and greeted Festus.

verses.name: Acts 25:14
verses.text: And as they stayed there many days, Festus laid Paul's case before the king, saying, "There is a man left prisoner by Felix,

verses.name: Acts 25:15
verses.text: and when I was at Jerusalem, the chief priests and the elders of the Jews laid out their case against him, asking for a sentence of condemnation against him.

verses.name: Acts 25:16
verses.text: I answered them that it was not the custom of the Romans to give up anyone before the accused met the accusers face to face and had opportunity to make his defense concerning the charge laid against him.

verses.name: Acts 25:17
verses.text: So when they came together here, I made no delay, but on the next day took my seat on the tribunal and ordered the man to be brought.

verses.name: Acts 25:18
verses.text: When the accusers stood up, they brought no charge in his case of such evils as I supposed.

verses.name: Acts 25:19
verses.text: Rather they had certain points of dispute with him about their own religion and about a certain Jesus, who was dead, but whom Paul asserted to be alive.

verses.name: Acts 25:20
verses.text: Being at a loss how to investigate these questions, I asked whether he wanted to go to Jerusalem and be tried there regarding them.

verses.name: Acts 25:21
verses.text: But when Paul had appealed to be kept in custody for the decision of the emperor, I ordered him to be held until I could send him to Caesar."

verses.name: Acts 25:22
verses.text: Then Agrippa said to Festus, "I would like to hear the man myself." "Tomorrow," said he, "you will hear him."

verses.name: Acts 25:23
verses.text: So on the next day Agrippa and Bernice came with great pomp, and they entered the audience hall with the military tribunes and the prominent men of the city. Then, at the command of Festus, Paul was brought in.

verses.name: Acts 25:24
verses.text: And Festus said, "King Agrippa and all who are present with us, you see this man about whom the whole Jewish people petitioned me, both in Jerusalem and here, shouting that he ought not to live any longer.

verses.name: Acts 25:25
verses.text: But I found that he had done nothing deserving death. And as he himself appealed to the emperor, I decided to go ahead and send him.

verses.name: Acts 25:26
verses.text: But I have nothing definite to write to my lord about him. Therefore I have brought him before you all, and especially before you, King Agrippa, so that, after we have examined him, I may have something to write.

verses.name: Acts 25:27
verses.text: For it seems to me unreasonable, in sending a prisoner, not to indicate the charges against him."

verses.name: Acts 26:1
verses.text: So Agrippa said to Paul, "You have permission to speak for yourself." Then Paul stretched out his hand and made his defense:

verses.name: Acts 26:2
verses.text: "I consider myself fortunate that it is before you, King Agrippa, I am going to make my defense today against all the accusations of the Jews,

verses.name: Acts 26:3
verses.text: especially because you are familiar with all the customs and controversies of the Jews. Therefore I beg you to listen to me patiently.

verses.name: Acts 26:4
verses.text: "My manner of life from my youth, spent from the beginning among my own nation and in Jerusalem, is known by all the Jews.

verses.name: Acts 26:5
verses.text: They have known for a long time, if they are willing to testify, that according to the strictest party of our religion I have lived as a Pharisee.

verses.name: Acts 26:6
verses.text: And now I stand here on trial because of my hope in the promise made by God to our fathers,

verses.name: Acts 26:7
verses.text: to which our twelve tribes hope to attain, as they earnestly worship night and day. And for this hope I am accused by Jews, O king!

verses.name: Acts 26:8
verses.text: Why is it thought incredible by any of you that God raises the dead?

verses.name: Acts 26:9
verses.text: "I myself was convinced that I ought to do many things in opposing the name of Jesus of Nazareth.

verses.name: Acts 26:10
verses.text: And I did so in Jerusalem. I not only locked up many of the saints in prison after receiving authority from the chief priests, but when they were put to death I cast my vote against them.

verses.name: Acts 26:11
verses.text: And I punished them often in all the synagogues and tried to make them blaspheme, and in raging fury against them I persecuted them even to foreign cities.

verses.name: Acts 26:12
verses.text: "In this connection I journeyed to Damascus with the authority and commission of the chief priests.

verses.name: Acts 26:13
verses.text: At midday, O king, I saw on the way a light from heaven, brighter than the sun, that shone around me and those who journeyed with me.

verses.name: Acts 26:14
verses.text: And when we had all fallen to the ground, I heard a voice saying to me in the Hebrew language, 'Saul, Saul, why are you persecuting me? It is hard for you to kick against the goads.'

verses.name: Acts 26:15
verses.text: And I said, 'Who are you, Lord?' And the Lord said, 'I am Jesus whom you are persecuting.

verses.name: Acts 26:16
verses.text: But rise and stand upon your feet, for I have appeared to you for this purpose, to appoint you as a servant and witness to the things in which you have seen me and to those in which I will appear to you,

verses.name: Acts 26:17
verses.text: delivering you from your people and from the Gentiles- to whom I am sending you

verses.name: Acts 26:18
verses.text: to open their eyes, so that they may turn from darkness to light and from the power of Satan to God, that they may receive forgiveness of sins and a place among those who are sanctified by faith in me.'

verses.name: Acts 26:19
verses.text: "Therefore, O King Agrippa, I was not disobedient to the heavenly vision,

verses.name: Acts 26:20
verses.text: but declared first to those in Damascus, then in Jerusalem and throughout all the region of Judea, and also to the Gentiles, that they should repent and turn to God, performing deeds in keeping with their repentance.

verses.name: Acts 26:21
verses.text: For this reason the Jews seized me in the temple and tried to kill me.

verses.name: Acts 26:22
verses.text: To this day I have had the help that comes from God, and so I stand here testifying both to small and great, saying nothing but what the prophets and Moses said would come to pass:

verses.name: Acts 26:23
verses.text: that the Christ must suffer and that, by being the first to rise from the dead, he would proclaim light both to our people and to the Gentiles."

verses.name: Acts 26:24
verses.text: And as he was saying these things in his defense, Festus said with a loud voice, "Paul, you are out of your mind; your great learning is driving you out of your mind."

verses.name: Acts 26:25
verses.text: But Paul said, "I am not out of my mind, most excellent Festus, but I am speaking true and rational words.

verses.name: Acts 26:26
verses.text: For the king knows about these things, and to him I speak boldly. For I am persuaded that none of these things has escaped his notice, for this has not been done in a corner.

verses.name: Acts 26:27
verses.text: King Agrippa, do you believe the prophets? I know that you believe."

verses.name: Acts 26:28
verses.text: And Agrippa said to Paul, "In a short time would you persuade me to be a Christian?"

verses.name: Acts 26:29
verses.text: And Paul said, "Whether short or long, I would to God that not only you but also all who hear me this day might become such as I am- except for these chains."

verses.name: Acts 26:30
verses.text: Then the king rose, and the governor and Bernice and those who were sitting with them.

verses.name: Acts 26:31
verses.text: And when they had withdrawn, they said to one another, "This man is doing nothing to deserve death or imprisonment."

verses.name: Acts 26:32
verses.text: And Agrippa said to Festus, "This man could have been set free if he had not appealed to Caesar."

verses.name: Acts 27:1
verses.text: And when it was decided that we should sail for Italy, they delivered Paul and some other prisoners to a centurion of the Augustan Cohort named Julius.

verses.name: Acts 27:2
verses.text: And embarking in a ship of Adramyttium, which was about to sail to the ports along the coast of Asia, we put to sea, accompanied by Aristarchus, a Macedonian from Thessalonica.

verses.name: Acts 27:3
verses.text: The next day we put in at Sidon. And Julius treated Paul kindly and gave him leave to go to his friends and be cared for.

verses.name: Acts 27:4
verses.text: And putting out to sea from there we sailed under the lee of Cyprus, because the winds were against us.

verses.name: Acts 27:5
verses.text: And when we had sailed across the open sea along the coast of Cilicia and Pamphylia, we came to Myra in Lycia.

verses.name: Acts 27:6
verses.text: There the centurion found a ship of Alexandria sailing for Italy and put us on board.

verses.name: Acts 27:7
verses.text: We sailed slowly for a number of days and arrived with difficulty off Cnidus, and as the wind did not allow us to go farther, we sailed under the lee of Crete off Salmone.

verses.name: Acts 27:8
verses.text: Coasting along it with difficulty, we came to a place called Fair Havens, near which was the city of Lasea.

verses.name: Acts 27:9
verses.text: Since much time had passed, and the voyage was now dangerous because even the Fast was already over, Paul advised them,

verses.name: Acts 27:10
verses.text: saying, "Sirs, I perceive that the voyage will be with injury and much loss, not only of the cargo and the ship, but also of our lives."

verses.name: Acts 27:11
verses.text: But the centurion paid more attention to the pilot and to the owner of the ship than to what Paul said.

verses.name: Acts 27:12
verses.text: And because the harbor was not suitable to spend the winter in, the majority decided to put out to sea from there, on the chance that somehow they could reach Phoenix, a harbor of Crete, facing both southwest and northwest, and spend the winter there.

verses.name: Acts 27:13
verses.text: Now when the south wind blew gently, supposing that they had obtained their purpose, they weighed anchor and sailed along Crete, close to the shore.

verses.name: Acts 27:14
verses.text: But soon a tempestuous wind, called the northeaster, struck down from the land.

verses.name: Acts 27:15
verses.text: And when the ship was caught and could not face the wind, we gave way to it and were driven along.

verses.name: Acts 27:16
verses.text: Running under the lee of a small island called Cauda, we managed with difficulty to secure the ship's boat.

verses.name: Acts 27:17
verses.text: After hoisting it up, they used supports to undergird the ship. Then, fearing that they would run aground on the Syrtis, they lowered the gear, and thus they were driven along.

verses.name: Acts 27:18
verses.text: Since we were violently storm-tossed, they began the next day to jettison the cargo.

verses.name: Acts 27:19
verses.text: And on the third day they threw the ship's tackle overboard with their own hands.

verses.name: Acts 27:20
verses.text: When neither sun nor stars appeared for many days, and no small tempest lay on us, all hope of our being saved was at last abandoned.

verses.name: Acts 27:21
verses.text: Since they had been without food for a long time, Paul stood up among them and said, "Men, you should have listened to me and not have set sail from Crete and incurred this injury and loss.

verses.name: Acts 27:22
verses.text: Yet now I urge you to take heart, for there will be no loss of life among you, but only of the ship.

verses.name: Acts 27:23
verses.text: For this very night there stood before me an angel of the God to whom I belong and whom I worship,

verses.name: Acts 27:24
verses.text: and he said, 'Do not be afraid, Paul; you must stand before Caesar. And behold, God has granted you all those who sail with you.'

verses.name: Acts 27:25
verses.text: So take heart, men, for I have faith in God that it will be exactly as I have been told.

verses.name: Acts 27:26
verses.text: But we must run aground on some island."

verses.name: Acts 27:27
verses.text: When the fourteenth night had come, as we were being driven across the Adriatic Sea, about midnight the sailors suspected that they were nearing land.

verses.name: Acts 27:28
verses.text: So they took a sounding and found twenty fathoms. A little farther on they took a sounding again and found fifteen fathoms.

verses.name: Acts 27:29
verses.text: And fearing that we might run on the rocks, they let down four anchors from the stern and prayed for day to come.

verses.name: Acts 27:30
verses.text: And as the sailors were seeking to escape from the ship, and had lowered the ship's boat into the sea under pretense of laying out anchors from the bow,

verses.name: Acts 27:31
verses.text: Paul said to the centurion and the soldiers, "Unless these men stay in the ship, you cannot be saved."

verses.name: Acts 27:32
verses.text: Then the soldiers cut away the ropes of the ship's boat and let it go.

verses.name: Acts 27:33
verses.text: As day was about to dawn, Paul urged them all to take some food, saying, "Today is the fourteenth day that you have continued in suspense and without food, having taken nothing.

verses.name: Acts 27:34
verses.text: Therefore I urge you to take some food. It will give you strength, for not a hair is to perish from the head of any of you."

verses.name: Acts 27:35
verses.text: And when he had said these things, he took bread, and giving thanks to God in the presence of all he broke it and began to eat.

verses.name: Acts 27:36
verses.text: Then they all were encouraged and ate some food themselves.

verses.name: Acts 27:37
verses.text: (We were in all 276 persons in the ship.)

verses.name: Acts 27:38
verses.text: And when they had eaten enough, they lightened the ship, throwing out the wheat into the sea.

verses.name: Acts 27:39
verses.text: Now when it was day, they did not recognize the land, but they noticed a bay with a beach, on which they planned if possible to run the ship ashore.

verses.name: Acts 27:40
verses.text: So they cast off the anchors and left them in the sea, at the same time loosening the ropes that tied the rudders. Then hoisting the foresail to the wind they made for the beach.

verses.name: Acts 27:41
verses.text: But striking a reef, they ran the vessel aground. The bow stuck and remained immovable, and the stern was being broken up by the surf.

verses.name: Acts 27:42
verses.text: The soldiers' plan was to kill the prisoners, lest any should swim away and escape.

verses.name: Acts 27:43
verses.text: But the centurion, wishing to save Paul, kept them from carrying out their plan. He ordered those who could swim to jump overboard first and make for the land,

verses.name: Acts 27:44
verses.text: and the rest on planks or on pieces of the ship. And so it was that all were brought safely to land.

verses.name: Acts 28:1
verses.text: After we were brought safely through, we then learned that the island was called Malta.

verses.name: Acts 28:2
verses.text: The native people showed us unusual kindness, for they kindled a fire and welcomed us all, because it had begun to rain and was cold.

verses.name: Acts 28:3
verses.text: When Paul had gathered a bundle of sticks and put them on the fire, a viper came out because of the heat and fastened on his hand.

verses.name: Acts 28:4
verses.text: When the native people saw the creature hanging from his hand, they said to one another, "No doubt this man is a murderer. Though he has escaped from the sea, Justice has not allowed him to live."

verses.name: Acts 28:5
verses.text: He, however, shook off the creature into the fire and suffered no harm.

verses.name: Acts 28:6
verses.text: They were waiting for him to swell up or suddenly fall down dead. But when they had waited a long time and saw no misfortune come to him, they changed their minds and said that he was a god.

verses.name: Acts 28:7
verses.text: Now in the neighborhood of that place were lands belonging to the chief man of the island, named Publius, who received us and entertained us hospitably for three days.

verses.name: Acts 28:8
verses.text: It happened that the father of Publius lay sick with fever and dysentery. And Paul visited him and prayed, and putting his hands on him healed him.

verses.name: Acts 28:9
verses.text: And when this had taken place, the rest of the people on the island who had diseases also came and were cured.

verses.name: Acts 28:10
verses.text: They also honored us greatly, and when we were about to sail, they put on board whatever we needed.

verses.name: Acts 28:11
verses.text: After three months we set sail in a ship that had wintered in the island, a ship of Alexandria, with the twin gods as a figurehead.

verses.name: Acts 28:12
verses.text: Putting in at Syracuse, we stayed there for three days.

verses.name: Acts 28:13
verses.text: And from there we made a circuit and arrived at Rhegium. And after one day a south wind sprang up, and on the second day we came to Puteoli.

verses.name: Acts 28:14
verses.text: There we found brothers and were invited to stay with them for seven days. And so we came to Rome.

verses.name: Acts 28:15
verses.text: And the brothers there, when they heard about us, came as far as the Forum of Appius and Three Taverns to meet us. On seeing them, Paul thanked God and took courage.

verses.name: Acts 28:16
verses.text: And when we came into Rome, Paul was allowed to stay by himself, with the soldier that guarded him.

verses.name: Acts 28:17
verses.text: After three days he called together the local leaders of the Jews, and when they had gathered, he said to them, "Brothers, though I had done nothing against our people or the customs of our fathers, yet I was delivered as a prisoner from Jerusalem into the hands of the Romans.

verses.name: Acts 28:18
verses.text: When they had examined me, they wished to set me at liberty, because there was no reason for the death penalty in my case.

verses.name: Acts 28:19
verses.text: But because the Jews objected, I was compelled to appeal to Caesar- though I had no charge to bring against my nation.

verses.name: Acts 28:20
verses.text: For this reason, therefore, I have asked to see you and speak with you, since it is because of the hope of Israel that I am wearing this chain."

verses.name: Acts 28:21
verses.text: And they said to him, "We have received no letters from Judea about you, and none of the brothers coming here has reported or spoken any evil about you.

verses.name: Acts 28:22
verses.text: But we desire to hear from you what your views are, for with regard to this sect we know that everywhere it is spoken against."

verses.name: Acts 28:23
verses.text: When they had appointed a day for him, they came to him at his lodging in greater numbers. From morning till evening he expounded to them, testifying to the kingdom of God and trying to convince them about Jesus both from the Law of Moses and from the Prophets.

verses.name: Acts 28:24
verses.text: And some were convinced by what he said, but others disbelieved.

verses.name: Acts 28:25
verses.text: And disagreeing among themselves, they departed after Paul had made one statement: "The Holy Spirit was right in saying to your fathers through Isaiah the prophet:

verses.name: Acts 28:26
verses.text: "'Go to this people, and say, You will indeed hear but never understand, and you will indeed see but never perceive.

verses.name: Acts 28:27
verses.text: For this people's heart has grown dull, and with their ears they can barely hear, and their eyes they have closed; lest they should see with their eyes and hear with their ears and understand with their heart and turn, and I would heal them.'

verses.name: Acts 28:28
verses.text: Therefore let it be known to you that this salvation of God has been sent to the Gentiles; they will listen."

verses.name: Acts 28:30
verses.text: He lived there two whole years at his own expense, and welcomed all who came to him,

verses.name: Acts 28:31
verses.text: proclaiming the kingdom of God and teaching about the Lord Jesus Christ with all boldness and without hindrance.
